my personal preference "tristan und isolde" , like so many others, is the famous '60s bayreuth recording conducted by karl bohm with the unstoppable birgit nilsson and a gratifyingly musical wolfgang windgassen, along with christa ludwig, eberhard wachter, and martti talvela.  in other words, the sixties "a list".  it is a performance that is simply mesmerizing in such a way that it has enthralled wagner devotees now for over four decades, with no sign of its' legions diminishing.  what is even more important about this recording is that the male lead, wolfgang windgassen, is an artist, whatever his virtues might be, who was never ordained vocally to sing the wagnerian tenor roles he specialized in for over two decades.  it is as good an example as one can make that an intelligent singer can sing for a very long time, even in a repertoire he wasn't exactly born to do.  windgassen, it seems to me, had the rare gift of being absolutely objective about his limitations, and by finding a way to sing this difficult music without ever overstepping those limitations, enjoyed a long, successful and i am sure gratifying career.  and this brings one to the tristan on this present recording.  placido domingo, it seems to me, truly understands his voice, its' strengths as well as its' limitations, and has seldom been tempted to step outside the boundaries he has set for himself.  the reward for doing that is a career that is now in excess of four decades.  four decades!  it boggles the mind.  and what is the downside of this rare intelligence?  well, it is obvious.  there are certain roles he would probably have loved to sing that he simply felt were not wise for him to do.  at least on stage.  one of them, i am quite sure, was tristan.  i am sure he could have done the role on stage.  i am equally sure it would have taken its' toll, as it almost invariably does.  domingo withstood the temptation.  and now, in the twilight of his career, he offers us a recorded tristan that is really quite remarkable.  he retains a great deal of the beauty his voice had when we all sat up and took notice of him 30 or more years ago.  his vocal line is intact.  the role, though relentless, is not high, which allows domingo to avoid the precarious high notes any tenor in his mid-60s might be concerned about.  and, of course, it allows him to sing a roll that concentrates its' range in that part of domingo's voice that still works beautifully.  so, here we have a tristan sung very well, perhaps even the best ever recorded, at least in stereo.  that said, domingo doesn't quite portray the anguish required in act three.  in fact, at least to me, he sounds just a bit light of voice, if you can imagine, in the final pages of his role.  i think for a tenor to really pull off act three he needs stage experience in the roll.  listen to windgassen.  or even the great jon vickers in the karajan set.  they have that extra something here which actual on stage performance gives.  nina stemme is quite fine here as isolde. admittedly, it is not possible for me to tell if she has been abetted by the recording engineers.  i can only go by what i hear, and i hear a very fine artist taking measure of a difficult role, and, on all counts, equitting herself well.  if this recording is any evidence, she should have a fine career ahead of her.  the rest of the cast is first rate. pappano's conducting and the covent garden forces playing can not be faulted.  i found the digital recording, a first for "tristan und isolde", to be outstanding.  it is very wide ranging, and i imagine fairs best on sound systems that are up to the digital demands of today.  this is not, as i have said, the first "tristan" to be added to my collection.  and it is certainly not the only "tristan" in my collection.  but it holds a very special spot in my collection, and i am thrilled to have it.

the 2nd solo album from bonnie pointer is another self-titled album title, which features mostly remakes of motown oldies, featuring a purple cover with a drawing of her. ultimately, it is not as rewarding as her excellent 1st solo album released just one year prior to this that has a red cover. i don't know why the decision was to redo more old motown songs from the 60's , whether it was her decision, producer jeffrey bowen or motown . only 6 songs, with only 1 song being an original new song, deep in my soul, which is excellent! it is a ballad much in the vein of the inventive tunes on her 1st album. it's what this album should have contained more of - original music.   as for the other 5 songs, i guess since heaven must have sent you was a big hit, they combed the motown catalog for more classics to redo. it's far too many to have done. what should have been a step forward in doing more progressive music like on her 1st album, was instead a fatal error that pretty much ended her solo career. this easily could have been an ep, and probably should have been only that, not a 2nd full album of remakes. of these i can't help myself , jimmy mack, when the lovelight starts shining through his eyes are the best. the arrangements are at least new & different than the original versions. but really, how could she top the original versions. it's a case of overdoing it. even the presence of sly stone and freddie stewart paying on 2 songs doesn't add up to much, as well as ollie e. brown, truman thomas and nathan east - all top session men. i once read that there were more recordings done for her 2nd album, but they were shelved in place of this. grave error. this could have advanced bonnie's career had it been filled with great songs like her 1st. and why name it bonnie pointer like the 1st? all it has done is confuse people.   so, if you like bonnie's singing, and she sings great on here, or motown oldies remade, you'll like this. otherwise, get her 1st slo album - it is amazing. bonnie ledt motown after this album, and recorded one more solo album, if the price is right, in 1984 for the private i label. that is better than this album, features all original songs, and even has ruth & anita singing background vocals on 2 songs. the pointer sisters , of course, were now platinum recording artists with a string of hit singles and albums . a shame she won't be let back into the group, but since she left in 1978, that was it for her with her sisters as a group.   released in late 1979 on motown m7-929r1 with the purple cover. songs: i can't help myself, jimmy mack, when the lovelight starts shining through his eyes, deep inside my soul, come see about me, nowhere to run.

"mr. soul" has a cool james bong theme vibe to it and "just this one time" should have been a huge hit .. it begins slowly and cher sings it with pain and wisdom ... the climax is chilling and almost shocking as cher reaches for a high soprano voice. amazing. my favorite track has always been "stars." it is timeless and perfect. she sings like someone who has lived a lifetime and seen it all ... but was only in her late twenties when she recorded it. as a fan who owns every single album, i can say that this is cher's finest. to warner's i can only say: what the heck are you people waiting for?  release this masterpiece on cd already. please.

the movie came out. i work in an elementary school and am surrounded by kids constantly, so naturally i have to go see the cool (and quality) movies that excite the kids (and this one looked pretty good.) so i went to the theatre and thoroughly enjoyed the enchanting story and incredible imagination. so no disrepect to those aspects of the movie whatsoever.  but i firmly believe this movie would have not been what it was without the score. i can't remember the time i had heard a score that so well matched the story and emotion of a film. this movie is loosely based on a children's book and i think the music somehow brought along that literary magic. just listen to the music and you can tell more or less what part of the movie it is. i remember sitting in the theatre, stunned at how well this music supported the story.  thus, i am calling this storybook music. it's sweet, simple, and all the while completely joyous/powerful/sad/whatever the occassion called for. a little celtic touch completes the magic, not to mention those certain chords tying all the pieces together. i left the theatre believing the music was the best part of an already awesome movie and downloaded the album.  and here is an example of this music's power: my classroom, last week, was painted and recarpeted. this of course meant that moving back in was hell and at this time i still don't know where a quarter of my things are--including the cd player used for listening centers, story readings, and the five minutes after recess where i play instrumental music to calm down the kids. so instead i pulled out my music-playing phone and turned up the volume on this album. every student who had seen the movie immediately recognized what the music was (and became very excited and defeated the purpose of the calming down period).  if squirrly first graders are touched enough by this music to recognize it, well, i can't tell you a more powerful testimony.

i first heard christina perri from vh1's you oughta know artist and it was the song "jar of hearts"... i immediately fell inlove. it's really hard these days to find honest and truly talented artists. her voice is amazing. her lyrics are true, easy to relate to and put together nicely. her music is composed just right. she's just great to listen to and sing along with. this cd is so good...the only thing bad about it is it's only 5 songs...5 songs is not enough. i want more.  so, this cd was recorded in a studio with a live band, and in ways you can tell...in other ways, you can't. christina perri doesn't need all the digitally mastered beats and auto tune to sound perfect (which doesn't really sound perfect or cool, just annoying) although i will say i have times and moods when i enjoy it. my point is she's perfectly perfect without all that.  "bang bang bang" i actually liked a lot more than i thought i would just by listening to the :30sec clip. listening to the entire song, it's just a very fun song to sing along with...especially if you've ever had someone stomp on your heart (which who hasn't). the chorus (which was surprisingly catchy to me) says, "bang bang bang boy, you're going down down down boy...to the ground where you left my heart to bleed. bang! she shot you karma tastes so sweet!" the lyrics to the verses are a little less simple, not complicated but they say much more than the chorus and they're clever. this song gets 4/5.  "black & blue" is a little more mellow than the first track and probably my least favorite on this 5 track ep. i'm not saying the song is bad, because it's not at all. it is in fact very good. at 2:37 the song is pretty short and could've probably been better if she made it longer and added more to it. i can't really say a lot about it because there's not a whole lot to it. what little of it there is, is enjoyable to say the least. this song gets 3/5  "daydream" is another mellow song. lyrics, music, christina's voice...just make this an overall great song. the vocal patterns on this song are also very good. she has a very different style than most artists these days. she talks about just loving someone in her daydream rather than in real life so she won't get hurt even though they want to be together. at least, that's what i got from it. i think it's a very good song, especially lyrically because i know i've felt that way before. this song gets 5/5  "tragedy" starts off with what i would consider a "darker" feel/sound (which i love to hear this sound because it's not done very often). she goes on to sing in the chorus, "and i won't be made a fool, i don't call this love". i want to say this is my favorite track on the cd but then i think of the other songs and it's just so hard to choose!!! but right now i think i'm saying this is my favorite track on the cd!! haha. it seems like it's so full of emotion that you feel all the feelings you've had before about a certain situation. i love it. this song gets 5/5  "jar of hearts" is to my knowledge the most popular song of christina perri's at the moment and the first song i'd ever heard by her. i obviously think it's good to have looked into her further and purchased this cd as well. she has the video out for this song as well which i think is a beautiful music video. this is how i would want my music video to be if i ever had one. i love the darker look of black and white with ashes and/or dead rose petals falling all around, ballet/interpretative dance, etc. i just love it! back to the song...it's basically about a guy who is what some would call a "player", he goes around "collecting his jar of hearts and tearing love apart". it's another slower/mellow song with tons of emotion and a voice that sounds so pure and raw. this song gets 5/5  i've said a lot. overall this is a great album, you should buy it. you will love it, you will thank me. you will thank christna perri's parents for bringing her into this world to make awesome music for us to listen to. you will thank christina perri for following her dream/passion of music so that we can all listen to her. trust me.  i'm looking forward to a full length and i cannot wait.

capital cities' 2011 ep is for anyone who likes new order, postal service, cut copy, omd, latter-day everything but the girl, ladyhawke, phoenix, css, mgmt and similar bands; or fans of independent electronic music in general.  these five tracks are jam-packed with good ideas; from fresh beats to undeniable hooks, it's a quick joyride.  excellent lead-off track "safe and sound" epitomizes capital cities' approach of over-filling the 3-minutes running time with one delightful surprise after another.  just try not to dig it.  the mid-tempo burn of "i sold my bed, but not my stereo" is another highlight.  any mix tape nerds will get a kick out of the lyrics, and the guitar hook during the refrain is irresistible as well.  even the least good song, closing number "love away," has so many redeeming qualities (like a great guitar solo and tons of cool keyboard sounds) that the happy piano chord pounding and sunshine lyrics can't get too annoying.  this ep certainly whets the listener's appetite for a full length capital cities release.  bottom line: alternative/indie electronic and alternative/indie pop fans, buy this ep.  you won't regret it.  note:  at the time of this review, the entire ep is available to stream on soundcloud.

i always want to love whatever dido does, for she has an amazing voice that's extremely unique and expressive.  for the most part, this album certainly isn't something that i dislike, but the safeness of it all definitely turns it into a mediocre listening experience.  while the vocals are pleasant--though nothing past that--the music that backs her up sounds like someone playing around on one of those casio keyboards that i had a couple of decades ago, on which i'd hit a button and get a drum line, then hit another button and i'd get a bass line. . . .  this album is, quite simply, safe.  not once do i hear anyone here, vocalist or musician, challenging themselves to do something unique.  by the fourth song, my interest was completely gone, and there was nothing after that that brought my interest back.  i know that if i want to listen to dido, i'm going to put on "life for rent," because songs like "happy new year" (which is among the least-inspired songs musically that i've ever heard), "love to blame," and "day before we went to war"--and virtually the entire album--sound heartless and soulless without significant music behind them to flesh out her vocals.  in an interview, dido said that there were never any moments when making the songs here was difficult.  i believe that completely because it's very obvious that there was almost no challenge here.  safe, boring musical tracks backing safe vocal tracks doesn't add up to a work of art here--they add up to a collection of songs that will sell quite a few copies and make quite a bit of money for an established artist, but if this was the work of a new artist, dido wouldn't be gaining a following with this uninspired fare.

fanfare magazine, peter j. rabinowitz  over the last two decades or so, randall hodgkinson has received so much attention (including the grand prize of the international american music competition in 1981 ) and has made so many recordings as an accompanist and as a concerto soloist that it comes as something of a surprise to realize that he's only now issuing his first solo cd. whatever the cause, it's well worth the wait. hodgkinson, sometimes typecast as a specialist in 20th-century music, has settled on a program (misleadingly titled petrouchka and other prophecies) that tests the range of his interpretive skills. and in all four of these substantially different works, he shows himself to be a first-rate musician.  what's most appealing about these interpretations is their diplomacy. textures are clean but not glaring; rhythms are finely pointed but not high-strung; climaxes are strong but not crushing; phrasing is gracious but never cloying (try, for instance, the reflective middle section of the chopin); inner voices are encouraged to speak but never allowed to dominate the conversation. yet for all its tact, the playing could not be called neutral, much less reticent, for hodgkinson's superb sense of musical shape (supported by his exceptional variety of dynamics and nuance of articulation), coupled with lightness of spirit, invests all four performances with a strong sense of character.  thus, his thoughtful beethoven may not provide any radical insights into this familiar music, but it's nonetheless welcome as a reasoned counterbalance to the grittier, more volcanic readings one often encounters. his relaxed account of the chopin is refreshing, too, as an antidote to the dozens of overdriven recordings that choke the catalog. likewise, while his stravinsky lacks the virtuoso brilliance, say, of pollini's classic account, one can argue that hodgkinson's dance through the music makes more of its folk origins. best of all, thoughas one might expect from his finely gauged brahms and schumann performances with clarinetist jonathan cohler (ongaku 024-102; 17:6)is his exquisite schumann: a kaleidoscopic reading that manages to place each piece in a different sound world without compromising the overall intimacy of the cycle. the engineering, too, is as seemingly natural as the playing. all in all, a most welcome debut.

my original cd was accidentally cracked... finding it available on mp3 here on amazon, instant buy. with michael knott, terry taylor and the late, great, gene eugen.... you can't go wrong!  knott's river of love is one of my all time favorites of his, clearly my favorite on the album.  we even played it as our exit music at our wedding, as we walked the isle, nearly 21 years ago.

the pathos of this work is undeniable.  michael knott and friends (terry taylor and gene eugene along with a few musicians, many of whom knott collaborated with in different bands including the aunt bettys) all provide gut level emotion checks throughout these songs.  the checks won't double you over in pain, won't knock you stupid to the floor, or leave you with a blistered feeling; theyll make your heart ache though, and your mouth curl up, your eyes squint as you see pictures and moments beyond your mere current confined sight, and theyll make your mind relax with alacrity bending toward the lord of hosts.  they supply melodic, often piano punctuated and acoustic guitar formed music that delivers pleasant vibes while surrendering personal, touching anecdotes.  floated out to the contemporary christian music (ccm) market of its time it truly was an alternative to the typical praise and worship fare.  it was quiet, introspective, personal.  it didn't need to mention jesus in the verse or chorus, or chant i love you god! in redundant repetition.  it spoke of personal love, often quiet and in struggle, with family and community and savior without ever naming names but also in unmistakable fashion (check out the poignant and almost mesmerizingly simple never forsaken as a grand example).  and these songs could get stuck in your head while ministering to your heart; they could slip from your lip and take on the outpouring of your spirit in petition to the almighty.  its worth your ear to hear.  knott was the vanguard for this project and it can rightly be considered a michael knott project.  his voice covers 7 of the 11 songs (the better known terry taylor lead vocals 2, gene eugene 1, and robert hammond 1) and i believe, though i may be wrong, he wrote or co-wrote all of the non-traditional songs on this release.  michael was a pioneer in the alternative christian music underground scene (as were taylor and eugene) and while he did have several songs where he wore his faith on his sleeve, even if on unconventional shirts or sporting musical tattoos, he rarely ventured into the ccm mainstream or toward what could be described as more traditional praise and worship music/ songs.  this project is the closest he ever came, and its leagues beyond traditional p&w.  its also deeply affecting and introspective.  it displays a mans heart who bleeds brokenness, hope, and mercy.  my only real complaint about this album is that it is a little inconsistent due to its track arrangements (the bouncier songs are all up front with the pared down songs trailing at the end; it doesnt bog the release down but the album could have flowed a bit better if they were arranged to break up these patterns).  4.75 stars.  if youd care to read further and test your eyes and patience im willing to test a few observations about these songs and share some of their lyrical content.  1) on my feet again ~ lead vocals: terry taylor.  wonderful paired piano and guitar give this somber tune its signature sound, along with taylors familiar vocal warble.  the middle is the coldest; somehow its always near, just like these indecisions round my neck all these years.  high, high, high, high.  you put me on my feet again.  high, high, high, high.  without you going nowhere. 2) window ~ lead vocals: gene eugene.  this song shows genes brilliance in his singing and its one of my favorites.  a very sad and yet open-hearted song.  drove all night in fear id die, got lost in the land of popeye, played another gig for no one, slept in a cat-hair bed, headed down to atlanta, passed a poor family that looked in love, smoke was rising up from their grill, they looked at me and smiled.  i see you out my window, in the fields of the forgotten. 3) river of love ~ lead vocals: michael knott.  probably the most accessible and pop-oriented song on the album.  absolutely wonderful, lively piano perfectly playing around a nice rhythm laid out by bass first and then drums.  great song and imminently singable, though knott mumblesings at times!  risen you are, holy you are, the giver of life, the giver of light, the lover of souls, the doer of righteousness.  pour me a bucket from your river of love. 4) simple man ~ lead vocals: taylor.  brings a bit of alt-country flavor to the mix. 5) everything for stormie ~ lead vocals: knott, who talks his way through the songs verses.  mike gives us a glimpse into his home life.  the sound of the song is upbeat, mellow, happy.  the story is a tempered reflection of absent fatherhood with wonderstruck awe of a childs love for their parent. 6) shine ~ lead vocals: knott.  michael has had a penchant for penning thoughts a little left from center and thats on grand display here.  living like a church mouse, looking for scraps, hiding from the cats up somewhere near the bats, deaf from the bell, i hear by what i smell, anyone got some cheese?  i might be lost and disillusioned, i might be running from the wrong side, i might be cracked up and confused, but you're still gonna shine.  nice, pleasant and smooth bass guitar undergirds the rest of the music. 7) call on you ~ lead vocals: knott.  absolutely fantastic and heartbreaking song.  simple piano line and singing, thats all.  call on you most often when it seems that i will never win, getting black and blue, beaten to a pulp by mis-choosed avenues, light i see down the street somewhere turns chilly; dark by the time i get there, everyone is fooling me with happy smiles and half sympathies.  some day ill know you with a smile.  some day ill see you like they do.  but for now ill call on you for help, and cash for bills overdue, and strength that i can influence right, little one i hold so tight, like slingshot breaks, snaps a hand, i know one day ill understand. 8) never forsaken ~ lead vocals: knott.  a song that has become a classic and one that michael has often performed live.  very moving.  check out the live versions of this song on  live in nashvegas, on the quasi-compilation things ive done, things to come, and live at cornerstone 2000.  never forsaken, never low for more than awhile, never mistaken for anyone else but your child.  never left alone, never left alone.  never denied forgiveness and never pushed away, and never far from the goodness that falls from your paths way. 9) lamb of god ~ lead vocals: robert hammond.  a traditional worship song.  a call for god to have mercy on us. 10) holy, holy, holy ~ lead vocals: knott.  a traditional that was simplified and whittled down.  voice and acoustic guitar, with multiple voices joining in on the gently repeating hosannas. 11) within ~ lead vocals: knott.  a strummed guitar hits some almost out of tune chordage.  this song slow builds to each chorus.  effective.  knotts always been good at these types of bare bones structures.  within the tears of the man, we can cry, within the face of temptation, we can try, within the garden, we too can feel alone, within the lord we can live, we can live, within the lord.

this is one song to be left alone. hand-slap to the arranger.  my country tis of thee  glorious. absolutely glorious.  pledge allegiance / god bless the usa  beautiful. i wish the two songs were treated separately but this track is great as is.  america the beautiful / give me your tired, your poor  america the beautiful is stunning. if you're patriotic you will need a tissue to get thru these parts of the song. give me your tired is very nice but again, i wish this was a separate track.  so many voices sing americas song  this is a strange arrangement. it almost has an aaron copeland feel with the open, perfect 4th/5th/octave harmonies in the intro. then it goes to a pop feel throughout most of the song. some of the lines and harmonies almost sound like the carpenters! mutt is the lost dogs' most pop album in their discography. when i say "pop" i don't mean, of course, the kind of programmed fluff you hear on contemporary radio. i mean the kind of creative, lyrically-intelligent pop produced by groups like the beatles, simon & garfunkel, and joni mitchell. in fact, much of this album has a 60's pop feel to it (with a bit of folk mixed in). it's also the only dogs album without a country-western flavor to it. there are 9 covers of the members' original bands - daniel amos, the 77s, and the choir - and one new song ("i'm setting you free"). officially steve hindalong wasn't a dog yet, but he plays all of the percussion and also co-produces. not surprisingly (with hindalong at the helm), the production is really good and is the best sounding dogs album since gift horse.  so what's to like about this album? quite a bit, but here are a few highlights:  1. amazing vocals. while only a few songs have shared lead-vocals with all three singers, every song on mutt has some wonderful harmonies and background vocals. a few songs even sound better than the originals - most notably, "if you want to" & "ain't gonna fight it" by daniel amos, and "to cover you" by the choir. after listening to this album, "to cover you" has become one of my favorite choir songs of all time (i had heard it before, but don't remember it sounding this good).  2. outstanding new takes by one singer covering a song from one of the others' bands. terry taylor does an intimate, stripped-down rendition of "the lust, the flesh, the eyes & the pride of life" (the 77s). derri daugherty sounds wonderful on mike roe's "sunshine down" and is accompanied by matt slocum on cello, with taylor adding some nice vocal harmony.  and roe delivers a superb performance of hindalong & daugherty's "beautiful, scandalous night."  it starts out with just roe & some acoustic guitar, but gradually layers in more instruments (and some great background vocals) and turns into a beautifully arranged hymn of praise.  3. excellent selection of songs. none of them - with the exception of "the lust. . ." - are staples or hits from the bands but they're great songs. lyrically, they are among the bands' most vulnerable, reflective and worshipful songs. musically, all of the songs fit very well together, except for "it's so sad" which ironically is the least "sad" sounding song on the album (roe offers up this 77s original in a charged-up 50's/rockabilly style).  4. beautiful full-bodied guitar sound (both acoustic & electric). the music on mutt would be worth listening to even without the vocals. i love the jangly byrds sound on songs like "if you want to" and "to cover you," and the acoustic guitars sound so clear at times it almost feels like you're in the recording studio.  a couple last-minute notes. . . tim chandler (from daniel amos & the choir) plays bass on mutt and sounds amazing as you'd expect. also, hindalong plays the oddly named glockenspiel on several songs - a quirky but melodic sounding instrument similar to a xylophone. surprisingly, it fits quite well on this album (i especially like it on da's "grace is the smell of rain"). musically mutt may be the most subdued of lost dogs albums, but it's probably their most beautiful album - and certainly one of their best.

the 1963 roulette records re-release entitled strike up the band (r 25231) was in 1959 called count basie swings, tony bennett sings (sr 25072). this earlier lp (with a rearranged playlist) is so rare there are as of this date no ammy listings for it. my link here is to a cd version. the basie-bennett sessions were an unusual cooperative effort of two record companies, roulette and columbia. simultaneous to the former publishing this album, columbia also issued a bennett/basie set (with different songs) called in person! tony bennett, count basie and his orchestra. these two talents were made for each other. the count's powerful band inspired tony, while his great vocals gave energy back to the musicians. theirs was a symbiosis that produced great sounds, as this set clearly demonstrates. trumpeter joe newman is featured on "chicago." he plays with mute on "i've grown accustomed to her face" and "life is a song." al gray's trombone rings forth on "are you havin' any fun." billy mitchell's tenor sax is spotlighted on the album opener, "strike up the band." this set's change-of-pace lullabye, "growing pains" is an opportunity for bassist eddie jones and guitarist freddie green to shine. flautist frank weiss is the only other player on this quiet track. thad jones has a trumpet solo on "poor little rich girl." frank foster's tenor sax sings right alongside bennett on "plenty of money." weaving in and out of all these is the inimitable piano of william 'count' basie. side one [1:30] strike up the band [2:38] i guess i'll have to change my plans [2:02] chicago [1:29] with plenty of money and you [2:15] anything goes [2:51] life is a song side two [2:56] i've grown accustomed to her face [2:05] jeepers creepers [3:28] growing pains [3:30] poor little rich girl [2:43] are you havin' any fun total time: 27:27

isis was of their time, the mid-1970's, and ahead of their time as well. this 8 member all female band cooked up a diverse blend of rock, soul, funk, pop and jazz. carol macdonald was the leader/lead vocalist/rhythm guitarist, who had honed her craft for a solid decade with goldie and the gingerbreads in the 60's. with the drummer from that band, ginger bianco, she formed isis in the early 70's, a rock band with a horn section. keyboard player from the gingerbreads, margo lewis, would join right after this album was recorded. the music on here is amazing. the sheer power of their music hits you right at the start with waiting for the sonrise. it's music at full blast, with carol's strong vocal matched by the horn section, with a guitar solo by lead guitarist suzi ghezzi. comparisons to the other rock bands with horns - chicago and blood sweat & tears - don't do them justice at all. the music on this debut album is all over the map, but fits together as a cohesive, tight selection of songs and styles. the album has long songs with jams, beautiful ballads, funk, and a 30's style swing song, cocaine elaine, that closes this most amazing album.  the cover of the album was a bold statement in 1974. the 8 members are pictured nude , painted in silver metallic paint. the sheer boldness of the cover perfectly suits the music inside. an all-female rock band playing music with talent, integrity and experience. listening to this album, isis had many textures to their music. the balance of the crunching rock and funk tunes to some gorgeously written and arranged ballads is equal, and illustrate that isis could play everything. carol's songs, everybody needs a forever, and rubber boy, are heart-breakingly sung & played, with sumptuous melodies and arrangements. either song could have been a hit single. bassist stella bass contributes 2 funkier numbers, april fool and do the football. the longest song on the album, servant saviour, is an epic with a voiceover with someone reciting as jesus, with carol's vocal, and solos that make it more of a jam piece. thinking of the time period, this band could play music that was more for fm radio. and during that time, androgyny was huge. david bowie ,elton john, alice cooper, t. rex. it was the perfect time for isis to form, in all the diversity of music that was being made. why not an all female band of musicians who really could play ? buddah records signing them was tremendous. thanks to the vision of carol macdonald and ginger bianco, that this band existed and made music. all these decades later, it's time to catch up, and listen to music that i missed out on the first time around. certainly, they were trailblazers and barrior breakers in music and society. this is their 1st album, out of 3 albums total. it is isis at their best, and at full power.

i used to wonder why this album wasn't released on cd like the rest of bill's work, but now that i've heard it, it's pretty clear that cosby's producers didn't want to risk this recording contradicting the polished, strictly wholesome image that bill had been cultivating since the early '70s. no, you're not going to hear him cussing at length or talking explicitly about sex or anything, but nevertheless, the tone of this 1968 album alone is out of touch with the warm, inoffensive quality that his later work is known for.  the collection features two shows from the same night (hence the title) recorded at lake tahoe; the two acts are supposedly divided by the nature of their content, but with the exception of one skit, i felt that they were pretty similar in tone. the 8:15 performance ("the dinner show") has cosby interacting with and teasing the audience for 17 minutes before talking about golf, football, and religion for another 14; while the material is all "new" and hasn't been recycled in any of his other albums, it's not exactly laugh-out-loud stuff and generally sounds like space-filler for his "sports" album. disappointingly, half of the 12:15 show ("the late show") is bill simply repeating stuff from the first act.  luckily, he does tell a pretty entertaining story from his adolescence about braving getting beaten up to attend a party. he un-endears himself, however, by later talking about his marriage in vaguely unflattering terms and uttering a few homophobic comments during a story about drag queens. concerning the latter, he's obviously exaggerating some things he says for the sake of getting a laugh, but you do get the definite impression that - at least during this point in his life - cosby the equal-rights proponent was practicing a bit of prejudice of his own.  i've only listened to the album once, but i'm pretty sure that at no time other than his departure does cosby receive a prolonged ovation...and rightfully so. even if we are to completely ignore the uglier bits, not a lot of stuff on here is funny enough to merit a buy for anybody other than stalwart devotees who want to complete a collection.

a common myth among latter-day rock critics is that the beatles were revolutionary merely for writing their own songs, but joe bennett & the sparkletones were a remarkable group of teenagers who wrote and played almost all their own material in the late '50s. they scored only a few hits -- the biggest of which was "black slacks," an infectious cut with an arresting vocal gimmick -- but their material was consistently fun and accomplished. black slacks contains the group's abc-paramount and paris recordings from 1957-60, covering such can't-miss topics as homemade rockets ("rocket") and dance crazes ("do the stop"). "what the heck" has a hilarious vocal arrangement reminiscent of sid king & the five strings, while "number one on my list" pairs vocal gymnastics with an unusual descending chord progression that again points up this group's level of musicianship and inventiveness. this excellent and energetic music is highly recommended to collectors of '50s rock & roll.

50 years ago, in 1963, a small four-member group of lads from liverpool, england wrote and recorded a song that would become the true definition of an epidemic to be known as beatlemania; the recording was a tune called "she loves you". from ringo's thundering drum opening to the final "yeah, yeah, yeah" "she loves you" is two minutes and eighteen seconds of pure excitement. the song was featured prominently in the 1964 film "a hard day's night" during the television concert sequence that appears towards the end of the movie. the group also performed the song during their historic debut on the ed sullivan show in february of 1964. it also became a staple of their live concerts during that same year. in england, the song became their fourth-released single on the parlophone label, quickly going to number one in the u.k. in america, it was initially released on the small-time swan label, but flopped when it was first issued. after beatlemania exploded and dominated america in 1964, swan reissued the record and this time it became a huge hit, also reaching number one in the u.s. although it was available as a single in canada on the capitol of canada label, it made its american capitol label debut when it was included in "the beatles' second album". the swan reissue single is unique because besides being a fun and energetic track, the disc itself was shipped in an attractive picture sleeve, which shows a black-and-white dezo hoffman photo of the group from a 1963 photo session. that same image was also featured on the back cover to the american capitol debut album, "meet the beatles!" both "she loves you" and its b-side "i'll get you" were released as a single world-wide. the song "i'll get you" also has its own catch-phrase of "oh yeah". both songs are also on "the beatles' second album". they were released together again in the "past masters" compilations in 1988 and 2009. the songs are also in the "mono masters" 2-disc cd as part of the 2009 cd boxed set, "the beatles in mono". in 2004, the two songs were reissued together in "the beatles' second album" disc as a part of the 4-disc cd boxed set, "the capitol albums, volume 1". this set features the songs in both stereo and mono mixes. as no true stereo mixes of these two songs exist, capitol created a duophonic mix of the songs by tweaking the treble to one channel and boosting the bass to the other channel, thus simulating a mock-stereo listening experience. the same original mono mixes of both "she loves you" and "i'll get you" are included twice each in the 2014 cd boxed set, "the u.s. albums" as well as a stand-alone cd release of "the beatles' second album"  there are multiple label variations of the swan single that were released: 3 dj promo discs, 2 red-and-white standard releases, 1 orange-and-white label version, 1 blue-and-white label variation and 10 different black label releases. there were also 4 unique one-sided promo discs of the single's b-side "i'll get you", that were released to radio stations in hopes that they would add the song to their playlists. the single was finally released on the capitol label in america when it was featured as part of the beatles' capitol/cema juke box series in january of 1994. it was made available as a red vinyl disc. although the swan label folded within a few years, the recordings themselves have remained as something special. this is, without a doubt, the record that defines beatlemaina!

from 1956, when dalliance was in flower and maidens lost their heads (ekl 110) is the ninth elektra records 12" lp. it's based on a 1719 english book, 'songs of wit and mirth' or 'pills to purge melancholy' by thomas d'urfey. this album was the first of a "dalliance" series that elektra describes on their archives website as a 'cash cow" for the company. btw, jac holzman, the founder of elektra, appears in disguise on the second version of this lp's front cover. vocalist ed mccurdy is perhaps best known for his 1950 anti-war song, "last night i had the strangest dream." ed left his pennsylvania farm life at age 18 to pursue a singing career. he was in nightclubs in the early 1940s when fan dancer sally rand hired ed to sing ballads on stage while pushing her on a swing. before relocating to canada, ed was vaudeville straight man to comic jack e. leonard. he hosted two toronto cbc radio shows simultaneously, a daytime one for kids and an adult audience program at night. this is where mccurdy developed a liking for folk music and made friends with pete seeger, josh white, oscar brand and other folkies. a successful folk show at the village vanguard in 1950 was followed by the mccurdy family's move to nyc. rght around the time he was emceeing the george gobel show on national tv, ed signed with fledgling elektra. accompanying mccurdy for these recordings on guitar and banjo is erik darling. also, a young alan arkin, former lead singer of the tarriers, plays recorder. some of these songs, wow! a few are obsessed with the touching of breasts and buttocks. check out "the trooper" for lyrics awash in private parts innuendo. "wanton trick" is about a maid who plays on a different sort of instrument. the naked maiden a-bathing attracts a young man who "leaped into her." "lusty young smith" with its "jingle-bang jingle" refrain comments on the negative effects multiple jingle bangs have on the poor fellow. penniless, three travelers pay a lady innkeeper, her cousin and a third young lady with something other than cash. answer to the "riddle" has a head but no face. side one [1:41] go bring me a lass [2:15] the trooper [2:15] a young man and a maid [2:21] a wanton trick [2:21] there was a knight [2:23] two maidens went milking one day [3:13] a lusty young smith [4:23] tom and doll side two [2:32] a riddle [2:44] a maiden did a-bathing go [1:45] the jolly tinker [1:37] old fumbler [3:03] the three travelers [1:18] kitt hath lost her key [2:12] to a lady [2:31] the four able physicians [1:47] sylvia the fair total time: 40:21

in 2001, when most other teenagers were listening to their cds, i began collecting records. i have amassed several records in the past thirteen years; but of all the records i own, this one brings me a powerful wave of emotions and memories.  i found this record in a thrift store in belton, missouri, in fall 2008 when i was a senior at calvary bible college. i had already purchased the cd "neil sedaka sings his greatest hits", and thought it would be fun to have some bonus material to play on my turntable. but as i listened to these songs, i came to the conclusion that they were actually better than his "greatest hits". and i began to identify very strongly with the content of side b of the album. at the time i had begun to fall in love with a freshman at cbc who was a very wonderful, sweet young lady. i was able to open up to her in a way that i never had been able to open up to anyone else before. it felt wonderful to be with her, especially after a previous relationship ended abruptly and left me looking at "the world through a tear" and stuck with a "one-way ticket to the blues". this freshman girl was my "alice in wonderland". she was my "sunny". i dared to hope that she might be "the answer to my prayer" and told her i loved her.  alas, she could not find it within her to return my love, and that was the end of our relationship. i've been with other girls since, and they've all been nice; but i have yet to find one whom i can love as much as i loved that special girl at cbc. and every time i play this album, especially side b, and especially on a crisp fall day with a blue sky, i am overwhelmed with bittersweet memories of my senior year and that freshman girl. i remember how wonderful it felt to be with her, and at the same time i lament what might have been.  here's hoping rca re-issues this on cd someday...

paul whiteman volume 1, rca victor lpv 555. the lp dates from about march, 1968; the album is pressed on a purple "grape juice" rca victor label. track list: side one-- *whispering (rec. 8/23/20) --victor 18690 *japanese sandman (rec. 8/19/20) -- victor 18690 *anytime, anyday, anywhere (rec. 8/23/20) -- victor 18694 *my man (rec. 4/4/21) -- victor 18758 song of india (rec. 8/26/26) --electrical recut of acoustic victor 18777 *hot lips (he's got hot lips when he plays jazz) (rec. 6/23/22) --victor 18920 three o'clock in the morning (rec. 8/25/26) -- electrical recut of acoustic victor 18940 *i'll build a stairway to paradise (rec. 9/1/22) --victor 18949 side two-- rhapsody in blue (rec. 4/21/27) --victor 35822, electrical recut of acoustic victor 55225. this track is compiled from both sides of victor 35822 when day is done (rec. 6/8/27) *what'll i do (rec. 3/18/24) --victor 19299 love nest (from mary) (rec. 2/10/28) -- victor 24105 ???--this release number dates maybe late 1933 medley from anything goes (rec. 10/26/34) note: * denotes an acoustic recording, pre-1925 technology; the other tracks on the lp are electrical recordings. this album runs a theme that splits the side one as whiteman's pre-columbia "jazz" sides from mostly the 1920-1924/5 acoustic era, while side two concentrates on whiteman's semi-classical ...concert orchestra recordings. this lp covers mostly whiteman's earlier styles, which were staid dance arrangements with a little jazz influence (not a lot of standout solo works; mostly the jazz accents have the reed or brass sections play together instead of letting one of the sidemen stand and blow), but you can clearly hear the jazz evolution cooking in the background and gradually becoming more prominent, especially in his later '20s period on the volume ii set paul whiteman, vol ii (lpv 570). for the most part, violins doubled with the trumpet section on the melody with most of these cuts. the 1927 electrical cut of "rhapsody in blue" compares favorably with a arthur fiedler & the boston pops version i have on cd, though the running time on this whiteman version is 8:48 (two sides of a 12" 78 rpm release), while fiedler's version runs to about 17 minutes. 78 rpm sides were limited to a playing time of 3:25 or so on a 10" pop release, while a 12" classical release could support about 4:30 per side or so. i've gleaned what record release numbers i can based on joel whitburn's pop memories 1890-1954 book pop memories 1890-1954: the history of american popular music, and and old edition of l. r. dock's 78 rpm price guide american premium record guide: 1915-1965: 78's, 45's and lp's, but the numbers are best guesstimates based on the recording dates - record dates in the release series. it looks like two of the tracks on side one are later '20s electrical recuts, which was not an unheard-of business practice at the time (er, dot records in the '60s rediscovered massively recutting artists' other labels' hits for several years on lp). sound is excellent, sourced from rca victor's a&r library masters.

over their eight-year existence, the chad mitchell trio consisted of four different lineups (mike kobluk being in all). on their 1964 mercury red label album reflecting (sr 60891), the mitchells were chad, mike and joe frazier. this most-familiar combo released nine lps in total. "reflecting" was their highest charter, peaking at #29 on billboard's top album chart. recorded under milt okun's direction late in 1963, this set includes a tribute to recently slain president kennedy. "in the summer of his years" was first heard two days after the tragic events of 11/22/63 on bbc's "that was the week that was." the mitchells immediately covered and combined it with a civil war anthem. also here is "the first time ever" (i saw your face), a song later popularized by roberta flack. in a lighter vein is shel silverstein's "the hip song," which explores the inability of a "cool" dude to communicate with regular folks when using his own slang. never shying from the political fray, the mitchells open by firing a satiric broadside at conservative sen. goldwater with "barry's boys." tom paxton's "what did you learn in school today" claims in verse what the firesign theatre expressed comedically with their everything you know is wrong album. more traditional folk songs are represented by "drill ye tarriers drill" and "queen elinor's confession," an elizabethan's-eye view of royal hanky-panky. two tracks come out of wwii: "banks of sicily" and "sinking of reuben james." with the passage of decades since their disbanding, the mitchell trio has faded into relative obscurity compared to more "commercial" outfits like the kingston trio and peter, paul and mary. musically however, this group was their equal, and content-wise, superior. most highly recommended! program-- side one: [3:48] barry's boys [3:07] the virgin mary [1:59] the tarriers song [2:09] what did you learn in school today [3:29] the hip song (it does not pay to be hip) [3:18] the banks of sicily side two: [2:36] tell old bill [3:14] queen elinor's confession [2:45] stewball [1:56] the first time ever [3:07] the sinking of reuben james [2:13] medley: in the summer of his years/rally round the flag total time: 33:41

after a two or three year hiatus from recording because of a lawsuit garner filed against columbia for releasing certain recordings without his consent, garner returned to the studios in 1961, under his own label, octave, and recorded one of his most inspiring albums of all (if his famous concert by the sea had the sound quality if would have had a much better chance for a 5-star rating),  dreamstreet; the title cut is one of the shorter cuts of the album, but it is one of garner's better piano jazz ballads. some of the most uplifting and awe-inspiring garner performances can be found here. the first time i heard his version of an old big band era classic made famous by big band leader tommy dorsey, "i'm gettin sentimental over you" it brought tears to my eyes. and believe me i am truly not one for over-sentimentality, melodrama or vanilla tunes. but in the hands of garner, a tune such as this one gets infused with such a sincere and palpable feeling, the performance really glows and if one listens to it real intently as i did, i felt a glow and few shivers down my spine. his swinging take of "the lady is a tramp" is filled with so much verve and energy that it makes you go right through the roof with joy and it even has a moment where erroll qoutes the famous "wedding march" theme played at the end of countless weddings right after he states the rodgers and hart theme. other highlights that will make you feel good are his oklahoma! medley of three songs from the show, and cole porter's "just one of those things"  garner plays mostly standards with showmanship and musical depth. i think that the variety of moods and textures at every moment make each song worth it. he, with the other members of his trio, entertains his audience beautifully, especially on the live album. his style is modern jazz, but not serious bebop like thelonious monk for example.  i understand that sometimes critics have questioned whether garner belongs in the mainstream of serious jazz. when listening to this recording that doesn't seem to me to be worth discussing.  track listing:  just one of those things i'm getting sentimental over you blue lou come rain or come shine the lady is a tramp when you're smiling sweet lorraine dreamstreet mambo gotham oklahoma! medley: oh, what a beautiful morning/people will say we're in love/surrey with the fringe on top  the trio:  erroll garner - piano kelly martin - drums eddie calhoun - bass  recorded on the octave label 1961 and distribured by am-par and is catalog number abcs 365 - this is the stereo pressing.  erroll garner is one of the most distinctive pianists of the jazz genre. other than thelonious monk, no one is more identifiable or harder to imitate. a self-taught virtuoso, garner devised a solo style that eliminated rhythm accompaniment. his hands worked totally independent of each other. with block chords he set the rhythmic tempo in his left hand, and with his right, he embellished on the tune, taking liberties with melody and time, often lagging behind the beat. some jazz purists dismissed him because he maintained his style throughout his career and enjoyed popularity unknown to most jazz artists. but garner's interpretive abilities and technical superiority cannot be denied.  one of the most distinctive of all pianists, erroll garner proved that it was possible to be a sophisticated player without knowing how to read music, that a creative jazz musician can be very popular without watering down his music, and that it is possible to remain an enthusiastic player without changing one's style once it is formed. a brilliant virtuoso who sounded unlike anyone else, erroll garner on medium-tempo pieces often stated the beat with his left hand like a rhythm guitar while his right played chords slightly behind the beat, creating a memorable effect. his playful free-form introductions (which forced his sidemen to really listen), his ability to play stunning runs without once glancing at the keyboard, his grunting and the pure joy that he displayed while performing were also part of the erroll garner magic.  this album marks the release of the first new work recorded by erroll garner in almost three years. after a history-making hiatus from recording, garner is here playing with the greatest freedom of his noteworthy recording career. these sides embody some of the most spirited, inventive, and moving garner performances ever recorded.  garner had unprecendented freedom in recording these works, a circumstance for which he, as prolific improviser, has long striven. time was no factor: there was room for experiment stretch out, and just "blow"-with complete surety that no material would he released without his personal approval. garner reveled in this atomsphere, as is evidenced by the material herein.  these sides are part of the works recorded by garner and his accompanists the first night, they played from 10 p.m. to 6:30 a.m., the engineer pleaded fatigue. the next evening, garner and company were back in the studio, resuming their uncharted flights into the world of improvisation. in an almost telepathic interplay with bassist eddie calhoun drummer kelly martin, garner soars into new orbit in these works.  those who know garner are aware of his creative chemistry which seems to refurbish itself and energize his accompanists and audience, the more he plays. this vitality permeates these recordings(punctuated by some irrepressible shouts and grunts of exhortation and amens which garner vents along with his mumbled head arrangement heard over the introduction to come rain or come shine.  each number in this album offers a facet of garner's diverse spectrum and rangy attack. his two part inventions played at impossible tempi are a tour de force, as in lady is a tramp, the oklahoma! medley, just one of those things. dreamstreet and mambo gotham were composed by garner at the sessions, joining his large group of originals (which includes misty, dreamy, solitaire, moment's delight, passing through). garner's unique time conception, and ballad "feel mark getting sentimental over you and sweet lorraine. when you're smiling and blue lou are romps.  acclaimed for almost two decades as one of the most original and individual soloists to emerge from the jazz milieu, the self-taught garner has been termed " .... a great natural artist, playing natural music." he is folk-based, in the aural tradition, an amalgam of some of the most primitive and most mature music of his time and culture. garner is one of the most widely imitated artists of his genre.  during garner's three year recording hiatus, many quick trends on the popular music scene, came and passed. all the while, with no regard to fads, "( ... gamer is always his own man at the keyboard ... a true innovator ... an original)" garner's intensive involvement with audiences throughout the world was heightened. his artistry transcends time and vogues. his public is of the most hybrid variety, embracing all ages, multi-backgrounds, many tastes.  for those who have not heard garner before, this album should be a treasure trove of discovery. for those who are perpetually rediscovering the creative well springs and joy of garner-who himself, is in a constant state of creative self exploration this long-awaited collection should hold reaffirmation and much gratification.

hello guys!  so i thought i had heard everything in classic rock (obviously that's not true!) but i have had the opportunity to have come across great "lost" albums, but never this one. shoot as you know (or not) was formed by former yardbirds drummer jim mccarty, and released this gem around 1973/74.  let me tell you that sometimes when you hear certain albums by bands that disbanded early in their career, the sound they had was a bit amateur, not bad, but still you could tell they were not blossomed enough (some got better or changed their musical direction).  the reason i came across this album was through youtube (yes, you can actually listen to the full album there) and what caught my attention was 1. the cover (very mistic and yet artistic) nothing rare about that since most bands at the time had great album covers. 2. the name-  simple and yet convincing and then came of course the music. it didn't remind me of any other group (though the song "the boogie" sounded like the band status quo), which is good because they had their own identity. very friendly album, good rhythm and most important moving. all of the 10 songs are interesting, good drums, very complete band. now, if only i could find this here panama (hardly) if only i could find this in cd ( hopefully, one day...) if only i could find this in vinyl ( i'll try) but then i would have to buy a record player, but then again for this album, it's worth it! saludos a mi futuro hijo, jorge octavio y a mi esposa jessy!

blame it on "feels so good" but chuck, a one-time superstar in the 1970s is way underappreciated today as the real musician's musician that he was. so much so that some of his greatest albums, like this one and "alive!" have never appeared on cd.  the bass / drum team of joey di bartolo and ron davis on "quartet" backing chuck and gerry niewood is in some ways even more sophisticated than on "alive!" a year later with steve gadd and tony levin. if you want more proof that the '60s produced the greatest, most soulful musicians of all time check these two out and how sensitively they synergize this transcendent band.  they create a jazz band sound with a true edge that is simultaneously smooth as silk without being soft!!!  that's what real rock and jazz are all about: edge born out of absolute integrity, even if it is just the integrity of soul put into 3 chords. when edge and high musicianship come together and are handled with grace and temperance, then you have the best of all worlds.  every tune here is a winner and the whole album flows seamlessly into one piece of art representative of one magical era in time (1971-1972) that will never come our way again except for inklings of its atmosphere of transcendence glimpsed by listening to albums like this. to top it all off, the definitive version of the much-overplayed brazilian standard "manha de carnival" is the cut that ends this album. not even wayne shorter and freddie hubbard on "wayning moments" can come close to the soul-drenched, bitter-sweet laid-back cool mixed with  equal amounts of high-energy flourishes that chuck and company bring to this old warhorse here.  get the lp, transfer it to cd and enjoy. i've generally found that lps transferred to cd maintain their warmth of sound especially if the playing surface is polished wtih mapleshade brand microsmouth polish to minmize laser jitter.

while greatest-hits albums from jazz artists are sometimes dubious propositions, dave brubeck is the rare exception to the rule. brubeck concentrated on the song as much as the performance, which is one of the reasons why he appealed to such a wide audience and it's also the reason why greatest hits is such an entertaining and effective sampler.  featuring such familiar items as "take five," "in your own sweet way," "the duke," "trolley song," "unsquare dance," and "blue rondo  la turk," the collection provides a fine introduction to brubeck's collegiate jazz for the uninitiated. time out remains the best place to start a brubeck appreciation, but this is an excellent 2 lp sampler.  track listing:  take five night and day i'm in a dancing mood castillian drums camptown races st. louis blues unsquare dance two part contention trolley song it's a raggedy waltz my favorite things let's get away from it all the duke coracao sensivel someday my prince will come blue rondo a la turk  the quartet:  dave brubeck - piano paul desmond - alto sax eugene wright - bass joe morello - drums  released 1974 on the columbia label and is catalog number pg32761. two lp set in a gatefold jacket.  very indepth liner notes by mort goode   this edition was never released to cd and is not to be confused with the dave brubeck greatest hits which has only 11 tracks as opposed to this vinyl edition that has 16 tracks.  without going knee deep into the dave brubeck canon, this is an excellent place to start your brubeck library. this contains all the important work of the classic dave brubeck quartet. i have this in my personal rotation and find it absolutely indispensible as a reference to this historic quartet.  well into the next century we will be listening and marvel to the music of dave brubeck and paul desmond. it is as timeless as the pyramids themselves. and dave is still with us, still composing and recording. dave brubeck has moved from icon to a true legend. no jazz library can be considered complete without dave brubeck cataloged, it just that simple.

so, here we were in late 1967, a year that saw that "manufactured band" the monkees (as some of the more unctuous critics liked to label them out of the mistaken belief that only they knew what good pop/r&r was all about) dominate the billboard top 200 album charts from the fall of 1966 with three straight # 1 lps, the monkees, more of the monkees, and headquarters spending 32 of the roughly 52-week span at the top spot, and displaced there by mainly the beatles' sgt. pepper's lonely hearts club band album from sometime in may 1967. even so, the album so replaced, headquarters, then held down # 2 for 11 straight weeks. not bad for a band that those critics (and the r&r hall of fame) refused then (and still do) to take seriously.  and wouldn't you know it, to further confound those "experts" this 4th album, pisces, aquarius, capricorn & jones ltd., as colgems 104, and which came out on november 6, 1967, promptly climbed to # 1 as well where it would stay for 5 weeks!. the album also produced the two-sided single hit pleasant valley sunday (# 3 billboard pop hot 100 in august 1967) b/w words (# 11 hot 100) as colgems 1007.  produced by chip douglas (who had used his birth name of douglas farthing hatlelid to produce headquarters), it had micky dolenz on drums (also guitar), mike nesmith and peter tork (also piano and organ) on guitars, and davy jones on percussion, are backed by drummers eddie hoe and kim copli, chip douglas (also bass) and bill martin on piano/organ, and douglas dillard on banjo. but the most notable aspect of this album, from an instrument aspect, was micky dolenz using his moog synthesizer, one of the first ever sold, on daily nightly and love is only sleeping, while paul beaver handles it on star collector.  the tracks (with writers shown brackets) are: a1. salesman (craig smith) (2:03); a2. she hangs out (jeff barry) (2:33); a3. the door into summer (chip douglas & bill martin) (2:50); a4. love is only sleeping (barry mann & cynthia weil) (2:28); a5. cuddly toy (harry nilsson) (2:45); a6. words (tommy boyce & bobby hart) (2:48); b1. hard to believe (david jones, kim capli, eddie brick, charlie rockett) (2:33); b2. what am i doing hangin' 'round? (lewis - clarke) (3:02); b3. peter percival patterson's pet pig porky (peter t ork) - pleasant valley sunday (gerry goffin & carole king) (3:30); b4. daily nightly (michael nesmith) (2:26); b5. don't call on me (nesmith & john london) (2:28); b6. star collector (gerry goffin & carole king) (3:30).  the cover is from a drawing by the noted cover artist bernard yeszin. the lewis -clarke team shown as writers for track 2 side 2 above were really michael martin murphey (as travis lewis) and owen castleman (as boomer clarke) who also recorded at colgems as the lewis & clarke expedition and who had a minor single entry of their own in 1967 with the # 64 i feel good (i feel sad) as colgems 1006.  at the same session developing this album, the band recorded i'm a believer and goin' down but instead of including them in the lp it was decided to release them as a single just ahead of the album. in nov-dec 1967, daydream believer soared to # 1 hot 100 (and stayed there 4 weeks) as colgems 1012 while goin' down reached # 104 on the bubble under charts.

i get a chance to play and perform these jazz octet arrangements by the best arrangers in hollywood (well...maybe the hollywood of a few decades ago...but that is a different matter).  this is a great example of the dave pell group.  the jazz improv here is of the "brief" variety and the arrangements do interesting things...each one has its own eccentricities, and they all change around constantly.  the style would probably qualify as "cool jazz", since the octet format has a number of different sound colors and the approach is not strictly bebop, but rather modern jazz as it was done in la around the late fifties and early sixties.  this album takes tunes that would have been known in colleges and especially in the south, and sticks them into the jazz octet world of dave pell.  all the tunes give plenty of soloing time, assuming you are not insistent upon extended form soloing like that of miles and trane.  if you are already familiar with the jazz at the lighthouse or the shelly manne and his friends style of jazz, then you will seriously dig this album....  i especially enjoyed hearing trombonist harry betts.  harry is also a great, great arranger and he plays great bone.  since i am a trombone player, i like to hear him.

for those who only know the gap band from hits such as "burn rubber on me" or "you dropped a bomb on me" should definately take the time and cash to search out this recording! it comes from what i refer to as the gap band's "first career".fresh from backup work for leon russell on his stop all that jazz album the gap band sound very very different on this,their true debut album (many think it was 1979's self titled mercury debut). their sound here is far gutsier,rootsier and more in keeping with their southern roots then they would be later on. that being said the gap band are very much fully formed here. they are able to deliver great funk with a tad of a sly stone twist (which is exactly what they do on the first three tracks) and one of them,"backbone" is just slick enough to join up with the best of their slick mercury area material. on "fontessa fame" they go even deeper with a very deep groove and a somewhat pecuiliar afro-centric percussion outro. surprisingly charlie wilson's vocals are already fully formed here and his shinning moment on this album is the piano-led deep soul ballad "you can always count on me",a straight-out-of-the-late-60's atlantic records/aretha style tune-at the end of the album charlie wilson pulls out an equally sweet northern soul turn in "loving you is everything". "bad girl",in keeping with the time period has a very strong "funkadelic" acid rock flavor to it. no matter how one cuts it the gap band were more then fully formed musically even at this primative stage in their development. one thing people had neglected to realize is that they were actually around a lot longer then even this album-growing and developing on sessions and live performances. so they were pretty fully formed by this point,even if most people don't even know this album exists.

when the maxayn band called it quits in 1974, the group did not die. rather, it morphed into one of the strangest projects that the motown label has ever recorded. this new group, born in 1977, was called mandre and kept the core of the maxayn group intact. this time the concept was futuristic space funk/disco complete with tons of synthesizers and blipping electronics. maxayn's hubby andre was at the helm, and album covers featured illustrations of his face covered by a mask, apparently (according to an insider) because motown thought andre was too ugly to show a picture of. ms. lewis was no longer singing lead in this group, but doing backup vocals, as well as songwriting and playing. and the motown promotions machine tried to hype mandre as being "funkier than parliament." (the preceeding commentary is from 'bold soul sisters'), commenting on the group, maxayn and lead singer maxayn lewis, but what this is about, is whether someone is locked in 'music genre' or if they want to listen to 'good music', one of mandre' cuts is still being played as the opening theme on philly's quiet storm segment hosted by philly's own 'tony brown', now that's longevity for you, which is a mark for 'good music'!!!

actually i could have done without the annoying tweeting sounds that are interspersed between tracks and even in some songs.  it's a gimmick that takes away from the music and maybe was a factor that hurt sales when the album was first released.  other than that the music here is some fantastic stuff.    you could almost slap this disc into a chicago sleeve and convince some listeners that it was something by that more famous horn band.  they sound like chicago on many tracks.  then there's the unique tracks like "shed my skin" that give myrth their own twist on the wind driven sound.    myrth is another one of the many bands that featured horns in rock/jazz arrangements that came out in the late 60's and early '70's.  they have a great sound with good songs in tight arrangements.  the musicianship is outstanding.  the vocals are star quality.    but then there's that incessant chirping sound.  oh well, if you can deal with it then you get a great big sound from a golden age when rock music was trying all sorts of different sounds.  this album is definitely worth a listen.  or if you like it as much as i did, many listenings.

note that this album is out of print, but is part of a value-priced set titled 8 classic albums as the first ten tracks on disc four. this 1962 album contains tracks that clearly show lewis' strategy to move from a jazz piano trio format to more popular music (perhaps in response to ray charles' success in crossing over from r&b to pop.) the first five tracks on the album have a string section backing the trio. while the first five tracks comprising side a is a foray into pop, side b is still heavily rooted in jazz. the album has a consistent theme - spring - and lewis contributed three compositions to reinforce that theme. he wrote a1, a3 and b1, and b5 was written by bassist eldee young. since there is no track list at the time of this review here are the tracks on the album: side a a1 sound of spring 2:30 a2 spring can really hang you up the most 4:25 a3 blue spring 3:00 a4 spring is here 4:22 a5 spring will be a little late this year 2:43 side b b1 spring fever 2:35 b2 it might as well be spring 3:52 b3 soft winds 3:10 b4 there'll be another spring 2:30 b5 truly, truly spring 3:27 the trio is comprised of ramsey lewis on piano, eldee young on bass and red holt on drums. the album was recorded for argo at the united recordings studio in los angeles on february 14 and 15, 1962 and released later that year. interestingly ruth brown (credited as the single artist who made atlantic records a name) and leonard chess of chess records have producer credits.

the fabulous hank turner, the golden country & western hits, columbia cl 1958 (mono)/cs 8758 (stereo)  the lp dates mid-late march, 1963.  song list on cl 1958/cs 8758: side one-- san antonio rose/i fall to pieces/sentimental me/he'll have to go/cold, cold heart/i can't stop loving you side two-- moon river/i can't help it (if i'm still in love with you)/please help me i'm falling/rose are red (my love)/tennessee waltz/i walk the line  playing time for this album is about 31:30.  small combo group, just incredibly basic lead instrumental work, played like background muzak for a roller skating rink.  the style is utterly dreadful, the blandest imaginable, sophomoric, lousy.  no swing, no groove, just whitebread, child's simplistic white pop.  note that the album includes some not-country pop songs:  "sentimental me," "moon river," and "roses are red" (i'm sure you get the andy williams-bobby vinton theme on two out of three; out of place on a country record).  taking a look at the credits, here's the explanation for the overall sound:  arranged, conducted, and produced by early '60s middle-of-the-road boring pop guy, robert mersey.  if this were a country album for columbia, the credits would run through the great don law & frank jones (ray price, little jimmy dickens, the good stuff).  this ain't an album for honky-tonk fans.  frankly, i think it's columbia's pop a&r's all-out april fool's 1963 joke album on country fans: there's no other hank turner records extant, only this and the 1968 chopped up harmony repackage (hl 7435 mono/hs 11235 stereo, dates june, 1968, missing "i can't stop loving you" and "i walk the line" cut off the 1963 full list lp.).  it's inexplicable that the marketing guys at columbia thought enough of this dreadful album to put out the mid-'68 harmony junker lp, then some time in the early '70s (?), put it out again on a columbia special products budget reissue as crsp 8758.  if there was a marketing reason for this album, it may have been as closer music when radio stations need a generic instrumental to close/fade out a music program segue into news or other programming (starday records made a ton of money with that marketing niche).  -???  if you're a fan of really, really horrible easy listening "...at the hammond organ" muzak and the deliciously perverted c&w song choices, this is a real treasure.  in my searches for music this bad, i've only found one other country "...at the hammond organ" album that makes me both spastically cringe and laugh so hard that tears run down my cheeks:  jimmy rhodes goes country.  if you can ever find that album (has a classic cheap private press lp "headstone" front cover art), grab it!
