this fine lp that was never released to cd, is the debut of brubeck's new quartet, a group featuring baritonist gerry mulligan, bassist jack six and drummer alan dawson.  recorded live in mexico, the album (unlike the previous bravo! brubeck which mostly stuck to traditional folk melodies) has three originals apiece from brubeck and mulligan, although the most memorable pieces are the two standards "adios, mariquita linda" and "amapola." this enjoyable set showed that for brubeck there was life after paul desmond.  track listing:  jumping bean adios, mariquita linda indian song tender woman (tierna mujer) amapola lullabye de mexico sapito recuerdo (remembrance  the quartet:  dave brubeck - piano gerry mulligan - baritone sax alan dawson - drums jack six - bass  recorded 1967 on the columbia label and is catalog number cs 9704. never released to cd.  review:  when 1967 and the 17-year-old dave brubeck quartet came to an end, two questions circumnavigated the world. was brubeck serious about concentrating on composing, and did this mean he was through as leader of jazz combos?  the answers respectively were yes and no. dave completed his long-envisioned oratorio, performed the premiere, with the cincinnati symphony, then turned his attention to a promise he had made to george wein just before the old group dispersed. wein had guaranteed to deliver brubeck, solo or with a group, at the second annual newport jazz festival in mexico.  brubeck had made a similar tour last year when american airlines, celebrating its 25th anniversary of servicing the country, arranged for wein to assemble a jazz package to play in puebla and mexico city. the reaction (commemorated in the "bravo! brubeck!" album) was such that this year there were calls not merely for a repeat but for an enlargement of the concept. in 1968, when the airline's baby became one of the many artistic projects of the so,-called "cultural olympics," the tour was expanded to cover five cities.  promptly, dave decided not to make it a solo jaunt. "i'd used jack six in the premiere performance of the oratorio, and of course he'd done some fine work with herbie mann's group and with george wein's newport all stars. it was george who recommended alan dawson as the best possible drummer i could find. he's worked with lionel hampton's band but he's best known as a member of the faculty at the berklee school of music.  "gerry mulligan had subbed in the old quartet for several nights when paul desmond was having some dental work done. since george already wanted to have, gerry on his mexican tour, i thought it would be exciting if we worked together."  traveling with the package (brubeck and mulligan, the adderley, mann and wein combos, singer clea bradford and woody herman's band), i was able to observe at first hand how swiftly and easily this excitement had been established. reports had already come in from the new orleans jazz festival about the ovation given to dave and gerry, topped only by louis armstrong himself. with only two full rehearsals and four u.s. concerts under their belt, brubeck and his three new collaborators evolved an immediate rapport. on and offstage, dave and gerry were as relaxed as i had ever seen or heard them.  before the group was two weeks old, a substantial repertoire had been assembled, composed of originals by brubeck and mulligan with a suitable sprinkling of mexican standards.  the gentle, delicate lullabye de mexico was written by mulligan some time ago, but gerry says, "i never knew what to do with it. but it seemed just right for this occasion."  dave has a special fondness for the beguiling indian song. "al walloupe, an indian vaquero on the cattle ranch where i was raised, used to hum incessantly the first two bars, which in reality was the complete song before i extended it. al would then laughingly explain that his forefathers would have sung that short melody for days at a time."  the public reaction to the new combo was consistently enthusiastic. during two prior visits, brubeck had been established as the most popular norteamericano jazz name in mexico. the addition of mulligan, and the curiosity value of hearing dave in a new context, reinforced an already fervent interest.  like the 1967 tour, the festival started in puebla before moving on to the bellas artes theatre and the national auditorium in mexico city. next came two shows in guadalajara, the first of which was a wildly acclaimed matinee held in a bullring. theatre dates in monterrey and acapulco ended the tour.  the new sounds introduced on these sides confirm the reaction of juan lopez moctezuma and other authoritative mexican critics: these four musicians combine the freshness and enthusiasm of newcomers with the intelligence and maturity of experienced artists.  for brubeck, mulligan, dawson and six, this was a tour that will not soon be forgotten - a happy, cooking ball for all. will they stay together? despite many other commitments, dave concedes that if wein works out a european tour, or anything else that will bring them together again, he won't make any show of resistance.  meanwhile, this will remain a unique and unprecedented album, a sui generis souvenir of a memorable week.

jerry vale, let it be, columbia cs 1021. lp dates mid-1970, on the stereo series between the end of cs 8000-9999 and the beginning of c 30000; columbia ran out of the old series stereo release numbers and started albums at the cs 1000 mark, which conflicted with the old mono cl 1000s from the late '50s. track list: side one-- easy come, easy go let it be i'll never fall in love again all i have to do is dream raindrops keep fallin' on my head jean side two-- love grows (where my rosemary goes) bridge over troubled water leaving on a jet plane something stay awhile best "serious" jerry vale find (his song, not everyone else's) on this lp is a stereo version of his a/c hit, "stay awhile," from 45 single columbia 45043, which charted on the billboard top 40 easy listening chart for a month, beginning in mid-february, 1970. the balance of the lp otherwise follows the clive davis contemporary covers formula that davis laid out in his 1972 bio. the two most out-of-place songs for vale's choice of material here is bobby sherman's bubblegum rocker, "easy come, easy go," and the edison lighthouse hit, "love grows (where my rosemary goes)" lp covers. bobby sherman? yep, a head-scratcher choice, that one. other covers you get belong(ed) to the beatles (a ballad choice, of course, "let it be,"), another beatles, er, george harrison tune (also done by label mate tony bennett on his odious keep-on-truckin' druggy hits cover album just a bit earlier, cs 9980 tony sings the great hits of today! ), a contemporary bobbie gentry/glen campbell 45 hit (cover), "all i have to do is dream, simon & garfunkel, a john denver/peter paul & mary hit, b.j. thomas, etc.... sound on this stereo lp is muddy; vale's vocals are centered and drenched in that sonic columbia "halo" echo, the string orchestra section is banked over on the left channel, piano, harpsicord, harmonica are banked right, and a very buried in the background male/female choral backing singers croon behind him. the entire album is buried in reverb; it's like hearing him some distance away down a long tile corridor. for the most part, other than vale's a/c hit, "stay while," the album is at best interesting if you have an urge for late '60s songs covered comfortably, forgettably, with two standout bubblegum teen pop songs done as a bizarre cure for insomnia. which, if you're looking for something so-bad-it's-good done in a narcotic relaxing operatic style, a five star experience.

christina perri is a very, very good songwriter.  i've been listening to her stuff and i prefer the arrangements of the songs on "the ocean way sessions" to the more recent versions on "lovestrong".  it's always a temptation for really good sound engineers to over produce and that's what they have done in her first full album, "lovestrong".  as an emerging artist i can't blame her for succumbing to the advice of the music execs.  take the wonderful song "arms" - a number of musical cliches have been added, the the worst being the sound of timpani.  the most apparant is her most popular song "jar of hearts", which is just so much better in this recording compared to the cheap strings that have been added to the background and the more poised, "correct" vocal in "lovestrong". i could go on but don't get me wrong, i still enjoy listening to "lovestrong", because the songs are so good.  it's just a shame the album is just a little to glossy and less honest than "ocean way sessions".  now these are arrangements where the raw emotion, thought-provoking lyrics, and wonderful melodic turns come through.  most of all, this ep is uncompromisingly honest.  if you read this christina, don't let them add too much gloss and musical cliches.  your songs don't have it, so why should the arrangements.  i look forward to hearing more.  your songs are just beautiful, and to be beautiful they need to be honest.  please give us more in the vein of "the ocean way sessions".

without question, dmitri shostakovich was one of the pre-eminent composers of the 20th century, often forced to compose works that reflected the dictates of a bunch of tin ears in the kremlin and the politburo in his native soviet union.  but the man knew his way around musical irony, which is clearly reflected in the fifteen symphonies that he wrote over a period of just slightly under half a century, beginning with his first in 1925.  and while those works were so blatantly misunderstood and misread by the elitists in his own land, they found favor on our side of the iron curtain because shostakovich had conducting friends in high places, especially here in america.  this is true of the composer's fifteenth and final symphony, composed in a shockingly short span of time in the summer of 1971.  typically large in terms of orchestral size, and moderate in terms of length (45-50 minutes), it is a work full of the composer's trademark originality and irony, though it also pays witty homages to some of his own past works, and alludes to such things as rossini's famous william tell overture, and the "fate" motif of richard wagner's famous (or infamous, depending on how one feels about him) ring cycle.  his own son maxim gave the work its world premiere recording in early 1972 with the moscow radio symphony orchestra.  but on our shores, the composer entrusted this symphony (and the two that came before it) to one conductor, eugene ormandy, and to one orchestra, the philadelphia orchestra, to give it its western premiere.  ormandy was always an active proponent of shostakovich's works; and this recording of the 15th symphony, made in october 1972, is proof of that.  it captures the composer's black wit in a way we'd expect all the great recordings of shostakovich to do.  the work's greatness shines through, as do ormandy and the fabulous philadelphians.  while we have had many fine recordings of this very modernistic work since this one (notably bernard haitink's 1978 recording with the london philharmonic), the ormandy/philadelphia one is still really the one that sets the standard, and it should be sought after without hesitation.

lenny dee was a versatile organist who enjoyed a top 20 hit with "plantation boogie" in 1955 and recorded a series of albums. he is best-known for being able to make his organ sound like a wide variety of other musical instruments.  dee was born in illinois, but raised in florida, where he learned to play piano when he was seven years old. after he began playing the piano, he also learned how to play accordion and banjo. in his late teens, he studied music in chicago. while he was studying, he began performing concerts on organ; during this time, he perfected his distinctive style.  dee began touring the u.s. after completing his studies. at a nashville concert, red foley was impressed with his style and brought the organist to decca records. dee signed a contract in the mid-'50s, releasing his first single, "plantation boogie," in 1955. the single became a hit, peaking at number 19. he followed it with his first album, dee-lightful!, which peaked at number 11. the hits dried up for dee quickly, though he continued to release records and tour. he returned to the charts in 1968, with his gentle on my mind album. two other hit albums followed -- turn around, look at me (1969), spinning wheel (1970) -- which peaked in the lower reaches of the charts. dee stopped recording in the mid-'70s.

this is a true 'best of' (at least in the mind of the producer) because the tracks are taken from eight different albums that were recorded between 1997 and 2006. what i find remarkable is there are three different bassists and drummers represented, yet the consistency of both music and mastering sound as though this album was recorded in a single session.  higgins' playing is, as always, beautiful. what hooked me as a fan is his attention to melody. he definitely has chops, but melody comes first.  he is also a genius when it comes to harmony. of course his rhythm sections are impeccable. one of the strongest pairings is jay leonhart on bass and the late, great joe ascione on drums.  run through the sound samples to get an idea of both the music and sound quality. to my ears both are superb.  all of the tracks are drawn from eight different albums, all of which were recorded for the venus label. that makes this album a perfect sampler if you want to learn more about higgins. i have recommended this as the ideal starter album for friends who are interested in higgins (or just wanting some exellent jazz piano trio music for their listening pleasure.)  here are the source albums:  tracks 1-3 are from the album titled haunted heart recorded at clinton recording studios in nyc on june 28, 1997. higgins is backed by ray drummond on bass and ben riley on drums.  tracks 4 and 5 are from the album titled bewitched recorded at the studio in nyc on january 30 and 31, 2001.  higgins is backed by jay leonhart on bass and joe ascione on drums.  track 6 is from the album titled dear old stockholm that was recorded at avatar studios in nyc during late september 2002. it features the same rhythm section as tracks 4 and 5.  track 7 is from the album titled amor that was recorded at the studio in nyc in mid september 2005. the rhythm section is sean smith on bass and joe ascione on drums.  track 8 is from the album titled if dreams come true that was recorded at avatar studios in nyc in early july 2004. the rhythm section is leonhart and ascione.  tracks 9 and 10 are from the album titled a fine romance that was recorded at clinton recording studios in nyc during sessions spanning october 14-17, 2006. the rhythm section is leonhart on bass and mark taylor on drums.  track 11 is from the album titled a lovely way to spend an evening that was recorded during the same october 14-17, 2006 sessions with the same rhythm setion.  tracks 12 and 13 are from the album titled you are too beautiful that was also recorded during the october 14-17, 2006 sessions with the same rhythm setion.

julie jean white silver heart- 8/1/2013  self released  run time 0:36:38  10 songs  julie jean white's resume is laden with tv and movie credits. first and foremost though; the minnesota native is a talented singer/songwriter.  her self-released debut, "silver heart" combines the purity of an independent artist with the polish of a seasoned veteran.  the album is thematically heavy. the 36 minutes deal with love and loss, domestic violence and women's empowerment. what makes the record so appealing is its simplicity. the instrumentation is sparse but rich. the jazzy electric piano on "daises" and the subtle pedal steel on "pillow talk talkin'" are just present enough to enhance but not overpower the vocals. white's mezzo is silky and authoritative. her naturally lower register gives her a singular ability to sonically convince the listener that a woman is still strong and in control even if the lyrics say she is vulnerable and beaten.  from the heartbreaking opener "undone" to the domestic turmoil of ""bridge i burn," the characters may be down, but  you never feel like they are out. on the latter tune, a woman gets shot but the listener still has hope thanks to white's reassuring voice.  she lightens up a bit with "a real man." it speaks to the value of the traditional male and is reminiscent of vintage bonnie raitt. she has won a bevy of awards, including american songwriter magazine's lyric contest and was a kerrville new folk finalist this year.  listening to this album is like sitting in the bluebird caf on a thursday night. this is pure talent.  for al the latest music news go to: [...]

two words: bad ass!  while i am a fan of the "land, air, sea" incarnation of the group and the sparse, power-trio dynamic their records offered up, pat wilson's solo approach has fostered a sharp, new sound that i would not have expected prior to purchasing this record.  what's not to like? the vocals boast a new air of confidence; the guitar tones are full of sharp teeth and swaddled in fuzz; the  drums are murky, highly compressed, and heavy-handed at times, crisp and seamless in others; the synth tracks and heavy feedback summon up memories of matt sharp's "rentals" and "pinkerton"-era weezer, and they seem to have added wholly new dimensions to the special g sound.  wilson combines these ingredients to whip his arrangements into furious, galloping, stampedes, which he corrals and controls seemingly without much strain or over-producing.  i can't express my overwhelming approval and appreciation for this album enough.  in my humble estimation, "natural" saved 2012 from being a total pop/rock failure.  while i would never openly hate on weezer, i truly feel like "natural" is head and shoulders above anything they've put out since "maladroit".  been waiting like a dog at the back door for this release for years.  do yourself a favor: spend the $6.00 and treat yourself to a kick-ass record.

respighi injects the score of this opera with the phrygian mode and augmented seconds to create an ancient, exotic, middle-eastern flavor. then he uses tone clusters in the strings to express the agony of his leading lady, silvana. he utilizes the best ideas of verismo, impressionism, and a few dashes of expressionism to create a true masterpiece.  the performers are excellent. ilona tokody (silvana) sings both with passion and with lyricism, despite a slow vibrato on her high notes. peter kelen (donello) has an exciting tenor. his love duet-scene with tokody at the beginning of act 3 is stunning. klara takacs has an unusual timbre to her mezzo, but nice energy, particularly in her low to middle registers (again with a slowed vibrato on top) in her part as eudossia.. sandor solyom-nagy's baritone does a wonderful job as the unfortunate basilio. katalin pitti is excellent in the small part of monica. the performing star of the show, however, is lamberto gardelli, who magnificently brings out the many mood changes of this amazing score. the chorus is solid. the sound quality is superb. the essay and libretto are very nice to have, although the font could be a bit larger.  the molinari-pradelli recording seems more widely available, probably because of the big name of anna moffo. although that live 1955 performance was fine, anna moffo's part is quite small and the sound quality just can't compare with this recording. even if it costs three times as much, this is the one to get.  in the final analysis, this is one of the very best "forgotten" operas. the only shortcoming may be that the lead character, silvana is less than admirable. in terms of the music itself, this could be the best opera of all time!

this is the one to get, still the finest version after more than half a century. the philharmonia has just the right sound--brash but refined when needed--and emmy loose has the perfect voice for the child's vision of heaven. and kletzki owns the symphony, meticulously registering all of mahler's detailed directions for balancing, expression, sudden tempo adjustments, and all else--not just mechanically following instructions, as many conductors do, but living and feeling the music as he performs it. the recording is mid-50s stereo, so it's all heard from a comfortable distance, but crank up the volume and everything comes through nicely. the nearest competitor so far is mackerras' new live recording on signum, similarly detail-oriented and in modern sound, but without that indefinable "rightness" heard here.

the new self-titled album from the multi-award winning balkun brothers is simply put, electric, incredible and rocking.  hailing from hartford, connecticut, the balkun brothers consists of guitarist/vocalist steve balkun, and his younger brother, drummer/vocalist nick balkun.  balkun brothers contains a dozen ripping white-hot blues-rock songs produced by one of my favorite blues guitarists, the amazing popa chubby.  from the get-go, the balkun brothers hit the ground running full speed with been drivin, serving hard-nosed blues with a heart-racing delivery. this song gets the adrenalin flowing like the mississippi.  they keep that energy going in i know what ya did, and she got it all, both full of catchy riffs and swampy slide guitar.  i get totally swept away in control yourself, and love the zeppelin-esque vibe present in cold heart.  the only cover song on the album, johnny winters mean town blues is a sheer delight.  steve keeps it rolling on guitar as nick keeps it tumbling with a cool hypnotic beat.  the album closes with the sweetly performed, acoustic selection rainy day front porch blues.  background audio of passing cars on a wet street add a nice touch of authenticity.  this fantastic album from the balkun brothers is brilliantly penned and has everything going for it.  it is destined to be one of this years favorites. porter wagoner was born in west plains,missouri in august 1927. he passed away in nashville tn on oct 28,2007.,from cancer at the age of 80. his career began in 1951  when he was 24 (2 years before hank williams passed away at 29)  and continued until the year of his death in 2007.  he was both a singer and songwriter and played acoustic guitar he had a long,popular career,made many album and performed shows for many years ,and was a regular on the grand ole opry. he and dolly parton performed together for several years,  this album was released in 1968 by rca victor (lsp-3968) .it is a vinyl,stereo lp and the sound quality is excellent. it was re-released in 2013 as a cd and again in 2015 as an mp3. it is an album of drinking songs;but not of the kind that are sung in bars for entertainment;but songs that tell the evils and heartacheand f the problems and tribulations of those who have had drink overcome them.  they are all very sad songs and carry the grief of those who have fallen in their lives. some of the songs are well known,while some are lesser known and may not be known at all or even forgotten ,even by wagoner fans. there are interesting notes on the back of the album cover from a local character in nashville who excerienced the trials and tribulations of alcohol,skid-row joe. these songs are very well written and there are many lines through them that only those who have experienced this world could write.  this is heartache country music at its best and seldom heard anymore.  porter wagoner was only  41 when this album was released and the voice you may remenbe in his later years was quite differe in 1968  "turn the juke-box up louder,they're playing our song"  all the songs on this album can be sampled on the mp3.
